text:
What's coming and going on Netflix in March.

What’s the best superhero series out there? Many would nominate Netflix’s “Jessica Jones“; the much-anticipated second season is coming in March. It headlines Netflix’s slate of original programing in March, which includes the limited series “Collateral,” a British crime drama written by playwright David Hare and starring Carey Mulligan, and new seasons of Netflix originals “A Series of Unfortunate Events,” “Santa Clarita Diet” and “Love.”

Original movies include the comedies “Game Over, Man,” featuring “Workaholics” stars Blake Anderson, Adam Devine and Anders Holm, and “The Legacy of a Whitetail Deer Hunter” with Josh Brolin and Danny McBride; high-school drama “First Match,” about a teenage girl on an all-boys wrestling team; hip-hop drama “Roxanne Roxanne” with Chanté Adams and Mahershala Ali; science-fiction thriller “The Titan” with Sam Worthington and Taylor Schilling; French-Canadian zombie thriller “Ravenous“; and a new version of the family-friendly adventure “Benji.”

Original documentaries include “Take Your Pills,” a study in the rise of prescription drugs used for performance enhancement, and “Ladies First,” about a young woman in rural India who became the top female archer in the world. Malala Yousafzai is David Letterman’s guest on his monthly talk show “My Next Guest Needs No Introduction” and there are stand-up-comedy specials from Ricky Gervais and Gad Elmaleh.

And yes, Netflix still streams movies. In March, it adds Martin Scorsese’s “Casino“; “The Fifth Estate,” starring Benedict Cumberbatch as Julian Assange; the original “Ghostbusters” and “Ghostbusters 2“; “Little Women” with Winona Ryder and Susan Sarandon; and the horror films “The Descent” and “Let Me In.”

Among the titles leaving Netflix in March are “Jaws” (and the unnecessary sequels); the Oscar-winning animated film “Zootopia“; animation-live-action collision “Who Framed Roger Rabbit“; Christopher Nolan’s “Memento“; and a whole slate of TV shows, including the animated spy spoof “Archer” and crime drama “The Killing.”

Here’s the list of what’s arriving and leaving on Netflix in March. Note that these are just highlights; Stream On Demand will be keeping an eye out for other notable films and TV shows that arrive through the month.

Dates are subject to change without notice.
